Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase goats

loans.name: Sri

texts.en: Sri, 56 years old, sells cakes and groceries. She earns 12 USD per day. She is a single mother who lives with three children. Two of her children work in the factory; each earns 2 USD per day. One more child stays home. Every month, she has to spend 100 USD on food, 5 USD on electricity, 20 USD on transportation, and 20 USD on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of 800 USD to buy a motorbike for her son to provide motor taxi services. She plans to open a tailoring shop for her daughter when she has enough money.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son to provide motor taxi services

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es: La señora Martha Lorena tiene más de 19 años con su negocio que es la venta de ropa usada. Solicita un préstamo para invertir en mercancía que es pantalones, camisolas, shorts, faldas, camisas, trajes para damas y caballero y además ropa para niños. Martha no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar la inversión que a su negocio le está haciendo falta es por eso que desea este crédito para comprar materia prima. Martha tiene algunos desafíos como es perdidas en algunas prendas de vestir que aparecen dañadas y ellas no las vende, pero a pesar de esto siempre está saliendo adelante.
texts.en: Martha Lorena has had her used clothes sales business for over 19 years.  She’s asking for a loan to buy more merchandise: pants, t-shirts, shorts, skirts, shirts, women’s and men’s suits and also children’s clothes.  Martha does not have the necessary funds to make this business investment so she’d like this loan to buy her raw materials.  Martha faces a few challenges like losses due to items of clothing that arrive damaged and are unsellable; despite this though she’s always moving forward.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Nuy's Group

texts.en: Nuy is 46 years old, divorced and has four children. Her two youngest daughters are still in school. She is a farmer and has been farming on her farmland for 30 years. She leads a group of two members. Nuy and the other member of the group are applying for their first loan from VisionFund to buy fertilizer for the farmland and plant more rice. Nuy hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield and earn more income to feed her family and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make some repayments on his taxi.

loans.name: Ruben Saturnino

texts.es:
Ruben nació en la  ciudad de Urubamba provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco y ahora vive en la misma ciudad donde nació, él tiene 42 años de edad y es casado y fruto de esta unión tiene dos hijos.

Ruben desarrolla sus actividades cotidianas y económicas en la ciudad de Urubamba, él es docente y trabaja en uno de los colegios más populares de la ciudad de Urubamba pero también se dedica a la venta de piñatería. Ya son once años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien. 

Ruben requiere el préstamo para comprar mercadería y así de esa forma poder abastecer su tienda de piñatería. 

Ruben se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. Ruben pertenece al banco comunal “Tercer Milenio” de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad de Urubamba.
texts.en:
Ruben was born in the city of Urubamba in the province of Urubamba in the department of Cusco and now lives in the same city where he was born. He is 42 years old and is married and from this marriage he has 2 children.

Ruben’s daily work activities take place in the city of Urubamba. He is a teacher and works at one of the most popular schools in the city of Urubamba but also he works selling piñatería (selling piñatas and similar items.) He has been in this business for 11 years and is doing very well.

Ruben is asking for a loan in order to buy merchandise so he can supply his piñatería.

Ruben is grateful for the opportunity given to him through this loan and at the same time he promises to make his payments on time. Ruben belongs to the communal bank Tercer Milenio of the Asociación Arariwa of the city of Urubamba.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as piñatas and festive hats and other items

loans.name: Segundo Augurio

texts.es:
Segundo Augurio tiene 27 años de edad es soltero no tiene hijos, vive con la madre en Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar.
Es integrante de la VRC PANGUA, se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad Pangua  Chaupiyacu, Parroquia Guanujo Cantón Guaranda, La comunidad esta a 15 minutos de la Oficina Los miembros de la Ventanilla Pangua se dedican la mayoría a la Agricultura y ganadería y también a otras actividades donde obtienen mayores ingresos económicos como: el comercio y la construcción.
Segundo se dedica a la Ganadería, agricultura y también se dedica a  ser albañil. Las compras los realiza en Guaranda. Solicita el crédito para comprar un terreno para poder trabajar en la siembra de maíz.
Con la ayuda del préstamo podrá mejorar la situación económica, El sueño es poder comprar un terreno. Los desafíos a los que se ha enfrentado es la sequía falta de agua a los cultivos.
En el tiempo libre le gusta descansar o también hacer deporte
texts.en:
Segundo Augurio is twenty-seven, single, and has no children. He lives with his mother in the Guaranda province of Bolivar.  He belongs to the Pangua village bank in the Pangua Chaupiyacu community in Guanjo Parish in the Guaranda canton. The community if fifteen minutes from the the office.  Most of the members of the Pangua office earn their living in agriculture, cattle farming, and other activities in which they can earn better incomes like commerce and construction.  Segundo works in cattle farming and agriculture.  He's also a mason.  He makes his purchases in Guaranda.  

Segundo is seeking a loan to buy a plot of land so he can plant corn.  With help from the loan, he'll be able to improve his financial situation.  His dream is to be able to buy some land.  The challenge he faces is the drought and lack of water for his crops.

In his spare time, Segundo likes to rest or engage in sports.

loans.use: to buy a plot of land for planting corn.

loans.name: Chantha's Group

texts.en:
Chantha is 39 years old, divorced, and lives in a village of the Thmor Koul district. Living as a divorced lady with three dependent children, she has struggled to feed her children by buying and selling vegetables as her primary business. She has been in this business for almost 15 years. 

Chantha and her group member, Muth, started taking loans with VisionFund in 2008. The loans have helped her to have regular income to feed her children. Now she leads a group of two members applying for another loan. She will use the entire loan to buy vegetables for sale. This loan will enable her to increase her business and earn a larger income to make a better living and save some money for her children.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for sale

loans.name: Atilana

texts.es:
La Sra. Atilana es de la ciudad de Itá, tiene 67 años de edad, está comprometida con el Sr. Mauro, se dedican al comercio teniendo una despensa en su domicilio, además de eso también se dedica a la compra y venta de carbón. Comenta que su esposo es quien la ayuda en el negocio y es por ello que están saliendo adelante.
Ella se define como una persona muy trabajadora y luchadora, ellos se esfuerzan a diario para poder tener una vejez digna. El deseo de ella es poder seguir creciendo y de esa forma tener un poco más de ingresos.
Atilana solicita el crédito para la compra de comestibles, bebidas, panificados, lácteos, enlatados y demás productos de primera necesidad. Ella agradece por la oportunidad de progreso que esta recibiendo.
texts.en:
Atilana comes from the town of Itá, she is 67 years old, she is in a relationship with Mauro and they engage in retailing by running a small store in their house. On top of this she also engages in buying and selling carbon. She says her husband helps her with the shop and it is thanks to his help that they are going ahead.
She considers herself to be a very hardworking and tenacious woman, and she and her husband work very hard on a daily basis to live their old age in a dignified manner. She wishes to keep on growing and to earn a better income.
Atilana is requesting a loan to buy groceries, drinks, backed and dairy products, canned food and other basic necessities. She is thankful for the opportunity to progress she is being given.

loans.use: To buy groceries, drinks, backed and dairy products, canned food and other basic necessities.

loans.name: Ephantus

texts.en:
Ephantus is a resident of Murang'a and has been in active farming for 15 solid years. His farm currently produces coffee, tea, and vegetables for the local market. He says his family fully relies on farming income for their daily upkeep. He is married with one child aged three.

Ephantus has requested a loan of 63,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says he wants to venture into dairy farming and plans to expand it to a capacity of 100 liters per day in under five years. He adds that the business could do well since there has always been a ready market for milk in the region. He hopes to uplift his family's living standards with the farming income.

He too laments of high cost of feed for the animals.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: El señor Juan José años se dedica al transporte escolar desde hace 13 años, trasladando a niños de preescolar, primaria y secundaria en turno matutino y vespertino para esto el tiene varias unidades en la que una maneja el y sus empleados. Para Juan José  es muy importante tener en perfectas condiciones los camiones ya que de esta manera podrá llevar a los alumnos con bien a sus casas. En este momento el quiere comprar una nueva unidad para sustituirla por otra que le está fallando de esta manera podrá ofrecer un mejor servicio. Este negocio es de suma importancia ya que es su única fuente de ingresos para sostener los gastos de la familia.
texts.en: Juan José has provided school transportation for 13 years, bringing kids to preschool, elementary school, and high school in the morning and evening. To do this he has various vehicles that he and his employees operate. To Juan José it’s very important to have the vans in perfect condition so he can bring the students to their homes safely. Right now he wants to buy a new vehicle to substitute for another that isn’t working, and in that way he will be able to offer a better service. This business is very importance since it’s his only income stream to pay for the family expenses.

loans.use: to buy a van.

loans.name: Sopha's Group

texts.en: Sopha, 32, is resident from Moung Russey district of Battambang province.  She strives for a living via corn farming and rice farming. Now, she is in need of working capital to support her cash-crops. So, she leads a group of three to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy rice seed and fertilizer for farm. She hopes to gain a good yield than before.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer for farm

loans.name: Banati's Group

texts.en:
The lady standing to the left hand side of the photograph is Banati.She is an enterprising and industrious lady who hails from a remote village of Koraput district,Odisha,India. Three years ago when her husband passed away, Banati was devastated.But with time she gained her confidence and took all the responsibility of her family on her shoulders. She currently has a family of four and is the sole earner of her family.She works hard in order to meet the ends of her family and provide a comfortable living to them.Banati is engaged in making incense sticks from last three years.She does this work from home s that she can balance her work as well as her house in an equal manner.However,due to lack of funds she is unable to increase her volume of production as per the customer's order.

Banati along with her group member is requesting for a loan amount of 30,000 INR from Kiva's partner Peoples Forum 
She will use her portion of the loan amount to purchase,ether,wooden sticks,scented powder,glue and packaging materials in bulk. The loan amount will ultimately help Banati to increase her volume of production and thus increase her income and enjoy a relatively higher standard of living.

Banati is in dire need of your kind help.

loans.use: to purchase,ether,wooden sticks,scented powder,glue and packaging materials in bulk

loans.name: Jose

texts.en: Jose R. is a 52 year old store owner who has had his shop for about 14 years. He is not married but has the responsibility of taking care of his 11 year old adopted son and his mother. His store is on the bottom floor of his home and is located well in order to attract clients from the area. With the loan Jose will buy more merchandise to sell at lower prices. Jose is completed dedicated to his business which is open from 6am to 11pm. His hard work and perseverance have allowed him to buy his home and fulfill the responsibilities of being a father.

loans.use: Buy in bulk to improve inventory

loans.name: Aklobessi

texts.en:
Born in 1949 in Zwola (Prefecture of les Lacs), Mrs. Aklobessi K. is widowed and has five (05) children, all of adult age. She has in her care two of her grandchildren, who are in school. Thanks to the weaving and sale of mats, she is able to meet her needs and those of her grandchildren. Currently, her straw mats are of very good quality, but wear faster than plastic mats. Mrs. K. recently learned plastic mat-making techniques and would like to start making them. She is a very dynamic woman who has mastered her craft. She has already benefited from two loans, both repaid, and deserves to be suported. Currently, Mrs. K. is asking for a loan of $650 to buy in bulk the basic materials necessary for the fabrication of plastic mats.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1949 à Zowla (Préfecture des Lacs), Madame K. Aklobessi est veuve et mère de cinq (5) enfants tous à l’âge adulte. Elle a à charge deux de ses petits enfants qui sont scolarisés. C’est grâce au tressage et à la vente des nattes qu’elle subvient à ses besoins et celui de ses petits enfants. Actuellement, les nattes en pailles sont de très bonne qualité mais résistent moins que les nattes en plastique. Madame K. vient d’acquérir la technique de fabrication des nattes en plastique et voudrait en fabriquer. C’est une femme très dynamique qui maîtrise bien son métier. Elle a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits bien remboursés et mérite d’être soutenue. Aujourd’hui Madame K. Aklobessi sollicite un crédit de $650 pour acheter en gros les matières premières nécessaires à la fabrication des nattes en plastique.

loans.use: To buy in bulk the basic materials necessary to make plastic mats

loans.name: Juana Fabiola

texts.en:
Juana is married and has a six month old baby. Her husband is a painter whose salary is not enough to cover the family's expenses. A year ago Juana decided to start her business to help her husband cover the expenses. Taking advantage of the fact that she lives in front of a school, she began to sell snacks and shoes.

Juana wants to offer her young son the very best, which is why she works very hard. Now she needs a loan of $250 to buy products for her stand and shoes that she gets orders for. She would like to grow along with her business. You can contribute to this, Juana is very thankful for your help.

Translated by Ari Vilhjalmsson, Kiva Volunteer.

Juana es casada y tiene un bebé de seis meses, su esposo se dedica a pintar casas, su ingreso no es suficiente para cubrir todas las necesidades de su familia. Hace un año Juana decidió iniciar su propio negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, aprovechando que su casa esta enfrente de una escuela, comenzó a vender frituras y botanas, así como también la venta de zapatos.

Juana quiere ofrecerle lo mejor a su pequeño hijo, por lo que trabaja muy duro. Ahora ella requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 250 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía para surtir su local y el calzado que le piden sus clientes. Ella quiere creer con su negocio y tú puedes contribuir a que pueda lograrlo, Juana agradece sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: Purchase products to sell in her stand

loans.name: Phun

texts.en: Mrs. Phun N. lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia with her husband and their 6 children.  Phun N. raises pigs and also makes rice wine.  She earns about $3/day in these businesses.  He husband, 42, is a traditional musician and plays for tourists around the Angkor Wat temple complex earning about $3/day.  All six of their children go to school, but right when they get home they help their mother with the pigs and also producing wine.  This loan will be used to purchase more pigs that will eventually be sold to market.  In the future, Mrs. Phun N. hopes to expand her wine business so that her children can have a better education.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs

loans.name: Dilrabo

texts.ru:
Dilrabo G. is 35 years old, she graduated from high school. She is a widow and has two children. Both are in school, and after school the older son helps with the retail business. After her husband's death 8 years ago, Dilrabo began her retail of children's clothing. She needed to have an income because, suddenly, she had to take care of everything.

In 2005, she received her first loan from MicroInvest. At that time, she obtained $90 and her savings were about $150. After receiving the microcredit loan, Gilrabo increased the variety of goods. Her current retail spot is very small, and she is planning to increase her retail space.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva Volunteer

Гозиева Дилрабо 35лет, образование среднее специальное. Она вдова, имеет два сына. Оба учатся в школе, после школы старший сын помогает матери в торговле. После смерти мужа начала торговать детской одеждой уже 8лет, так как все заботы и проблемы семьи свалились на её голову.

В 2005 году начала получать займ в МЗФ «Микроинвест», тогда она получила 90$, и её активы составляли 150$. После получения неоднократного займа она добавила в свой ассортимент и хозяйственные товары, но место для торговли у неё тесное и она планирует расширить место деятельности.

loans.use: To expand retail place

loans.name: Joumana

texts.en: Joumana A. is 45 years old and lives in the area of Ouzai, one of the poorest areas of  the Beirut suburbs. She sells detergents to her surrounding neighbors. She needs $900 to build up a large enough inventory of cleaning products. Being divorced from her husband, she strives to provide a good education for her 2 children with the money she earns from her small business.

loans.use: To buy cleaning products for her store

loans.name: Rosanna

texts.en: Mrs. Rosanna A. is 38 years old and married with 4 children. The family lives in Benin City. Rosanna specializes in the production of Polythene bags and needs a loan of $250 to buy more materials for the production of Polythene. This is a business she learnt for 5 months and then established her own business in 2006. She is a dedicated LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more material for the production of Polythene bags for sale

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
Reyna is a member of the community bank Nuestro Senor de Martha II. She sells umbrellas and lives int he Huarez district in the Huaraz province of Peru. Her business activities changes based on the time of year it is. She is mobile, and sets up her business in locations that are appropriate for the type of goods being sold. This month she is selling her products in the Christmas Market located in the city of Huarez that is open from the 10th of December until the 2nd of January. This market is located on the pier of the Quillcay River in the Huaraz province, department of Ancash.

With this 2000 soles loan, which will be paid back over the course of 8 months, she will purchase various merchandise to offer her clients for the Christmas festivities: 32 dozen stuffed animals, 8 dozen games, 3 dozen articles of clothing for women and men.

Reyna is a mother of 2 children. She is 32 years old, her husband is a taxi driver and has his own vehicle. Both Reyna and her husband work to contribute to their household expenses, and also to the fees and expenses associated with their children's education.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva Volunteer

La Señora Reyna pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuestro Señor de Martha II, se dedica a la venta de paraguas; vive el el distrito de Huaraz, provincia de Huaraz. Cambia de negocio según las temporadas del año. Ella es ambulante, se ubica en lugares adecuados según la ocasión. En este mes ofrecerá sus productos en la feria navideña en la ciudad de Huaraz que se lleva acabo desde el 10 de diciembre hasta el 2 de enero. Dicha feria está ubicada en el malecón del Río Quillcay, provincia de Huaraz, departamento de Ancash.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00 soles, el cual será cancelado en 8 meses, comprará mercadería variadas para ofrecer a sus clientas en estas fiesta navideñas: 32 docenas de peluches, 8 docenas de juguetes variados, 3 docenas de ropa tanto para damas como para caballeros.

La señora Reyna es madre de familia de 2 menores hijos y tiene 32 años, su esposo es chofer (transportista) y cuenta con movilidad propia, ambos se apoyan y trabajan para solventar los gastos de su hogar y de la educación de sus menores hijos.

loans.use: To buy stuffed animals, decorations, buttons and gifts

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Born on July 23, 1980 in Agoè (Golfe prefecture), Kossi A. finished middle school before he started his own business selling soap, sugar, milk and other goods. But because he lacks sufficient funds, his business is stagnant, and he is often faced with inventory shortages. This is why, in order to better equip his shop with other items and to increase his income, he is requesting a loan of $800 to buy cartons of soap, milk, and other canned goods at cheaper rates. He will then be able to maximize his income and to help to improve his family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Née le 23 juillet 1980 à Agoè dans la préfecture du Golfe, Monsieur A. Kossi a fait ses études jusqu’au collège, avant de se lancer dans le petit commerce de vente de savons, sucres, laits et autres pour son propre compte. Mais l’insuffisance de fonds fait que son commerce n’évolue pas et il est très souvent confronté à la rupture de stock. C’est ainsi que pour pouvoir mieux équiper sa boutique d’autre article, afin d’augmenter ses revenus, il sollicite un crédit de $800 qui servira à acheter des cartons de savons, laits et autres boites de conserves, ce qui lui revient moins cher. Ainsi pourra-t-elle avoir le maximum de revenus pour contribuer plus à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: To stock cartons of soap, milk, sugar, and canned goods

loans.name: Patrocinio

texts.en:
Patrocinio is a tailor who makes shirts and, more recently, school uniforms. In addition, his wife is active in the business; they started out with only a small amount of capital to invest, yet they now operate their own shop.

Patrocinio is seeking a loan to buy the necessary amount of fabric to make additional school uniforms for the children in their part of the city because they are currently unable to meet their customers' demands. However, with an increase in the amount of fabric on hand in their shop, they will be able to increase their production and, thus, their income.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials and fabrics to make school uniforms.

loans.name: Crucita

texts.en:
Crucita is in her late forties and she’s the mother of a large family. Actually, Crucita has five daughters and three boys, most of whom are in their twenties. To make a living and support her family, Crucita sells fresh pork in the Río Arriba community of Baní. Each day, Crucita goes to the butcher’s shop to purchase pork wholesale. She has a well-established clientele to retail it to.

The entrepreneur plans on using her loan to add chicken to her stock in order to attract more people and increase her income. Crucita’s business supports her children’s education.

loans.use: Purchase of chicken and pork for re-sale in her community

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a 39 year old single mother of three children ages 12,10 and eight. She also takes care of 1 other person, aged 59 years old. Asha started selling charcoal in 2008. Everyday, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Eao

texts.en: Eao K. is an elderly Khmer woman who lives with her widowed daughter, Chen Mei. At 76 years old, Eao K., is still laboring as a rice farmer in her home province of Kampong Cham. She has been farming rice since she was young in 1960, 15 years before the Khmer Rouge would come to power. She earns 1.50 US$ per day. Her daughter grows cucumbers. Eao K. has six children, some of whom help care for her by sending money each month. As she is very old she can no longer carry water from the well to her fields when not enough rain has come. She wants to buy a simple pump to use as an irrigation system for her fields.

loans.use: To buy a water pump.

loans.name: Dominga Geronima's Group

texts.es:
Dominga, Maribel and Marisol are members of the Musuq Rumi communal bank, which means "new stone" in Quechua.

Dominga is single and 25 years old. Dominga sells breakfasts at the entrance to the interprovincial bus company; she has a cart and works from 5 in the morning till 8 in the morning. Sometimes she sells candy outside of one of the schools.

Maribel lives with her partner, is 19 years old and is pregnant with her first child. Maribel sells candy as an ambulatory vendor, using a tricycle to get around the central streets of the city.

Marisol is married, 29 years old and has 2 children. Marisol is an ambulatory vendor in the Magdalena market and sells an anti-inflamatory topical rub; she works both mornings and nights.

Dominga, Maribel and Marisol need loans for 600, 400 and 1000 soles, respectively. Dominga will invest in purchasing bricks for building her house; Maribel will buy cookies, gum and candies; while Marisol will start a new business selling groceries.

Dominga, Maribel and Marisol dreams are to: have their own home, land, progress with their family and have a stable business.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Dominga, Maribel y Marisol son socias del Banco Comunal Musuq Rumi que significa Nueva Piedra en quechua.

Dominga es soltera y tiene 25 años, Dominga vende desayunos en la puerta de una empresa de transporte interprovincial de manera ambulatoria, tiene una carreta, actividad que realiza desde las 5 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la mañana. En algunas oportunidades vende golosinas en una academia.

Por otro lado Maribel es conviviente, tiene 19 años y esta embarazada de su primer hijo, Maribel vende golosinas de manera ambulatoria en un triciclo, se ubica en una calle céntrica de la ciudad.

Mientras que Marisol es casada, tiene 29 años y 2 hijos, Marisol vende emoliente de manera ambulatoria en el mercado Magdalena, actividad que realiza por las mañanas y las noches.

Dominga, Maribel y Marisol necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 400 soles, 1000 soles, Dominga invertirá en la compra de adobes para la construcción de su casa, por otro lado Maribel en la compra de galletas, chicles, caramelos, mientras que Marisol iniciará un nuevo negocio de venta de abarrotes.

Los sueños de Dominga, Maribel y Marisol son tener casa propia, un terreno, salir adelante con su familia y tener un negocio seguro.

loans.use: Dominga will buy bricks for building a home; Maribel will buy merchandise for her business; Marisol will invest in a new business selling groceries.

loans.name: Luz En El Camino-Group 3

texts.en:
Anita H. is a kind lady who is very enthusiastic about managing her business. She has been receiving loans from Esperanza for two years. She operates a shop where she sells items such as homemade bread and a variety of refreshments. She uses her loans to purchase the items that she sells and the bread ingredients.

Ms. H. is a mother of five children, ages 5, 10, 11, 13, and 19. The eldest lives with her sister. She is also a devoted member of her church, which is where she spends much of her free time. Her favorite foods are those that have coconut in them. Therefore, she enjoys making coconut specialty items to sell. Ms. H. hopes to see her business grow and provide a better life and further education for her children.

Ms. Anita H. is a member of a 5 person group (Group 3) that is part of a 30 person micro-bank called Luz en el Camino, which translates to Light in the Road in English. In the picture, Ms. H. is second from the right. She is with members of her group and other borrowers. Anita's story is just one of a list of men and women who are improving their quality of life through the help of Esperanza's micro-credit loans. This group has united with a common vision of a better life with faith and hope in their hearts and an unbreakable spirit. Each associate in this bank has a similar business, whether it is selling bread or operating a hair salon. Thank you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell in the store as well as ingredients to make bread

loans.name: Lafia (La Tranquilité) Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Lafia sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans et 5 enfants .Elles vivent avec leurs maris et enfants dans des familles monogames à Kamalen Sirakoro  un village  situé à  4 kilomètres de la ville de Sikasso ( Région de Sikasso  République du Mali).
Le groupe Lafia fait le commerce d’articles divers : les condiments alimentaires, les matériels en plastiques, en aluminium, les produits de cueillette (zaban, karité, graines de néré) les pagnes wax et du charbon de bois.  
Ce groupe constitué de consanguins, de voisins et d’amies emprunte ensemble à l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 4 ans. Il est à son neuvième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire) et a correctement remboursé tous les prêts précédents.  Avec ce prêt, elles vont achèter,  à Sikasso 250 paires de chaussures en plastique, 100kg de poissons fumés, 4 douzaines de marmite en étain, 125 sacs de charbon de bois et une quantité importante de condiments.
Les membres se ravitaillent à Kamalen Sirakoro sur place et dans les villages environnants pour les produits de cueillettes et le charbon de bois .Elles disposent chacune dans leur concession conjugale d’un magasin dans lequel elles entreposent jusqu'à avoir la quantité destinée à la vente. Elles effectuent leurs ventes : produits de cueillette, le charbon de bois etc. généralement les jours de foire dans le marché de Sikasso (au comptant à une clientèle féminine en provenance de Bamako, Ségou etc.). Pour les matériels en plastiques, les ustensiles de cuisine (de fabrication locale en aluminium) et les condiments alimentaires ils sont achetés au grand marché de Sikasso auprès des grossistes pour être revendus sur place au village où les villages voisins viennent se ravitailler. 
Elles espèrent avoir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA.qu’elles vont  utiliser  pour aider leurs maris dans les dépenses de la famille et payer les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
The members of the Lafia (lit. tranquility) group are married women who, on average, are 50 years old and have 5 children. They live with their husband and children in monogamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village located 4 kilometers from the city of Sikasso (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). The Lafia group sells various products: condiments, plasticware, aluminum items, gathered fruits (zaban, shea nuts, néré), Wax-brand pagnes (traditional print cloth) and charcoal. Made up of relatives, neighbors, and friends, this group has been borrowing from the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for the past 4 years. It is now seeking its ninth group loan and has properly repaid all previous loans. With this loan, the women intend to buy, in Sikasso, 250 pairs of plastic shoes, 100 kg of dried fish, 4 dozens tin saucepots, 125 sacks of charcoal and a large amount of condiments. The members do their shopping for gathered fruits and charcoal in Kamalen Sirakoro and in the surrounding villages. Each member store the purchased goods in their respective home, until they reach a sufficient stock to start reselling. Gathered fruits, charcoal, etc are usually sold (for cash and to a female clientele coming from Bamako, Ségou, etc) during fair days in the Sikasso market. Plasticware, cookware (locally manufactured aluminum items) and condiments are purchased from wholesalers in the grand market of Sikasso, and resold in the village, where people from the surrounding villages come to do their shopping. They hope to make a monthly profit of 25000 XOF each, to be used to help their husband with the family expenses, and to repay the loan.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plastic foodware, condiments, sacks of charcoal and cookware

loans.name: Aminétou

texts.fr:
Madame A. Aminétou est revendeuse de charbon dans un petit marché de Lomé. Née à Atakpamé en 1978, elle est aujourd’hui mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle achète du charbon dans les villages environnants et le revend à Lomé.
Son réel problème étant le transport elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter en grande quantité le charbon de bois pour un total de 15 sacs. Ainsi elle pourra réduire les voyages hebdomadaires d’approvisionnement afin de pouvoir économiser les frais de transport.
texts.en:
Mrs Aminetou A. is a retailer of charcoal in a small market place in Lomé. She was born in 1978 and today, is married and the mother of one child. She buys her charcoal in the neighboring villages and sells it in Lomé.

Her main problem has been with transportation and she is requesting her first loan to buy a large quantity (15 sacks) of wood charcoal. This way she would reduce the number of weekly purchasing trips and would save this cost of transport.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 15 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Charita

texts.es:
La Señora Charita es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Margaritas”, vive en la región San Martín,  provincia de El Dorado, distrito de Agua Blanca. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes  desde hace bastante tiempo y le va bien. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Arica C-03, lugar donde acuden diariamente a comprar sus clientes, los cuales son mayormente los vecinos de su  barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,700, el cual será cancelado en 6  meses, comprará  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, juguetes, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes marcas y tamaños, entre otros, para poder surtir bien el negocio y que los clientes encuentren lo que buscan. 

Charita tiene 32 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus 02 hijos. Es una mujer trabajadora, carismática y con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando para hacer crecer el negocio y además porque le gusta lo que hace. Su meta es continuar con el negocio, seguir creciendo y tenerlo bien surtido para la satisfacción de ella y la de sus clientes, así como también terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Charita is a member of the "Las Margaritas" Communal Bank, lives in the San Martin Region, El Dorado Province, Agua Blanca District. She has been in the business of selling groceries for a long time and is going good. The business is located out of her home located at Jr. Arica C-03. Her customers, who are mainly her local neighbors, come on a daily basis to shop at her store.

With this 1,700 soles (Peruvian currency) loan, which will be paid back in 6 months, Charita will buy products of basic need like: rice, sacks of sugar, boxes of preserves in different sizes, toys, packs of toilet paper, detergents, different brands and sizes of soaps among them. She want s to have a good assortment and variety of products so her clients can find what they are looking for.

Charita is 32 years old, lives with her husband and 2 children. She is a working and charismatic woman with a great desire to continue working to see her business grow and also because she loves what she does. Her goal is to continue with the business, continue expanding it, and offer a good assortment for her satisfaction and her customers as well. She will also like to finish building her house.


Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Will buy basic need products like rice, sugar and others

location.town: Agua Blanca - El Dorado - San Martín

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Zubeda Harufani from Mwanza, a beautiful city on the shores of Lake Victoria. (Lake Victoria is famous not only for being one of the largest lakes in the world but also because it feeds the Nile River, a very important source of life for Africa.)

Zubeda is married, with one child who is 3 years old. Zubeda has been running a plastic business since 2005. She purchases rolls of clear plastic, cuts the plastic, and seals one end to make bags that closely resemble the bags you receive when you purchase a fish from the fish store. She then bundles several bags together and sells them to vendors of all sorts, who may pile tiny mangos or figs into the bags to sell to people who pass by foot, car, or daladala (mini city buses).

Zubeda is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase additional plastic material and a machine that cuts the plastic. Zubeda thanks you for supporting her!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, so they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use their equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase plastic material to make bags and a machine that cuts the plastic

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn O. sells provisions in her shop. She needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She is 32 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en: Benedicta B. is single and has no children. She has received schooling through senior high. Since 2005, Benedicta has been selling groceries like biscuits, canned products, and other items at Intarbeton in Cape Coast. She uses her income to support her parents in paying utility bills and other basic expenses. Benedicta will use the loan to purchase additional groceries to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She will save the extra profit to be able to build a house before she starts a family.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries for sale

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing I. is 30 years old and married with 4 children. Her husband is a commercial driver.

She has a business selling fish. Among other items, she sells crayfish and prawns along with palm and vegetable oil.

Now, she needs a loan of N70,000 to purchase more fish to sell. She says thank you to all who will make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Chab

texts.en: C., 60, owns a medium dump truck for a transporting service for soil and firewood. He lives in Siem Reap Province and has 8 children; three of them are single and under his care and the other are married and live separately. He is married to Sor, 37, who is a local firewood seller. C. is running the business very well and he has a skill for attracting customers to his service. Unfortunately, C. can't provide his goods service as before because his truck has broken frequently. Therefore, he is asking for a loan of $1000 to repair his broken truck.

loans.use: To repair his broken truck he uses for his transporting business.

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr:
A. K. Ama est originaire du Togo, elle est née le 26/05/1973 à Lomé. K. Ama est mariée à KOUKPAGAN Christophe qui est comptable à UNITEC-Bénin. Ama a quatre enfants dont un garçon et trois filles qui sont tous scolarisés. L’ainé Jonathan est en classe de sixème. Ama vend des boissons de la Société Béninoise de Brasserie(SOBEBRA) du Bénin et des galettes faites à base de maïs. Ama est à son quatrième crédit. Ama sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son activité.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
A. K. Ama traces her roots to Togo. She was born on May 26, 1973 in Lomé. She is married to KOUKPAGAN Christophe, who is an accountant at UNITEC-Bénin. She has four children, a boy and three girls who are all in school. Jonathan, the eldest, is in the 6th grade. Ama sells beverages from Société Béninoise de Brasserie (SOBEBRA) in Benin and also galettes made from corn. She is on her fourth loan and is requesting this loan to bolster her business.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sack of corn and six cases of drinks

loans.name: Misitura

texts.en: Misitura A. is a 40-year-old married woman with four children. She sells cosmetics and has been in this business for a long time. Misitura is requesting a loan of 50 000 NGN to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: St. Francis A Kanyike Sarah Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sarah K. is a widow, age 48, with six kids (four still in school) and three orphans also in school. She will use the loan to purchase charcoal and water wholesale. She can't forget how hard it was when she started the business on her own. She thanks God that Kiva is serving as an instrument to sustain her business. Her dream is to see all the children she’s looking after grow up well.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and water wholesale

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria es una madre muy amorosa y trabajadora, vive en su propia casa junto a sus 3 hijos; Maria de 20, Tony de 23 y Lucy de 25, a quienes ama mucho y desea dar un buen futuro. Sus días comienzan muy temprano por la mañana cuando habré su tienda de abarrotes y empieza a atender a sus habituales clientes, su tienda es muy concurrida, ya que está situada en un lugar muy transitado, además, el carisma y la alegría que le pone Maria a sus ventas han hecho que su bodega se convierta en una de las principales de su barrio. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que puede realizar las tareas domésticas al mismo tiempo que atiende su bodega. Lleva 7 años en esta actividad y lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día dentro de su tienda sin poder salir a realizar sus actividades. Para el futuro, anhela mejorar la infraestructura de su tienda, hacerla más grande para que sus clientes puedan comprar con mayor tranquilidad. Este es el primer préstamo de Maria con MFP, se siente muy feliz de la oportunidad brindada, y está dispuesta a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, en su banco comunal es una socia muy responsable. Con los 1000 soles de préstamo, planea aumentar la cantidad de mercadería que vende, para mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Maria is a very hardworking and loving mother who lives in a proper house with her 3 children; Maria is 20, Tony is 23 and Lucy is 25 and she loves them so much and desires to give them a better future. These days she starts early in the morning when she opens her store and starts serving her repeat customers. Her shop is very busy as it’s located in a well trafficked location, also, the charisma and joy Maria brings to her sales makes her store a major part of the neighborhood.

The thing she likes most about the job are the domestic tasks and at the same time she enjoys attending to the shop. She has been at this profession for 7-years but finds it difficult to roam the store all day long without being able to realize other activities.

For the future, she’d like to improve on the infrastructure of the shop to make it better for her clients to shop with a peace of mind. This is the first loan for Maria through MFP and she is very happy to be able to have it and will be repay her debt promptly as she has a responsibility to her community bank. With this loan of 1000 soles she plans to increase her inventory of product to earn better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory of products

loans.name: Zubaida Anwar Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell.

Tayyaba Iram baji wants a loan to buy raw materials (sugar and dried fruit) for her sweetmeat-making business.

Nagina baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle

Aqeela baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for their milk-selling business.

Zubaida baji is the group leader for these above-mentioned ladies. They all belong to a historic place of the city of Lahore named Yadgar, Pakistan. Zubaida baji is married to Mr. A. who runs a sweetmeat shop. His variety of sweetmeats is famous with many people. Zubaida baji also helps him in the making of sweetmeats. She is applying for a loan to buy raw materials (cooking oil, sugar and dry fruits) to expand her husband's sweetmeat business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for sweetmeat-making business

loans.name: Tatiana Sinuk’S Group

texts.en:
Tatiana S. (the first person on the left in the photograph) organized a retirement home called “Sunshine” for people between the ages 60-90 years old. She started 5 months ago, after her mother’s death. “I didn’t give all the warmth and care I could to my own parents, so I am giving it today to my new guests,” Tatiana says. Today, Tatiana has 11 elderly people in the home and 5 staff workers.

Tatiana financed the retirement home entirely with her own money. The local government provided an old building (a former kindergarten) to use free of charge for fifteen years. Tatiana managed to make some small renovations in the building. She bought 20 beds (the total capacity is 60 people) and purchased equipment for the kitchen and dining room. Because “Sunshine” does not have enough cash assets, all of the workers work for free and hope to be paid a salary when better times come. Nowadays, the retirement home exists only with the aid of the retiree’s pensions.

Tatiana hopes to use loan money to purchase a cow and two sheep. Milk and meat from the livestock will be used for cooking. Also, some amount of milk and meat can be sold in the market. Additional food and all the necessary materials will be purchased. Also, Tatiana expects the older people to participate in the process of livestock breeding in order to fill their free time with an interesting hobby.

Tatiana S. is married and has three sons. She and her husband operate the retirement home and their sons try to help whenever they have free time. Tatiana comments: “I love this house. I feel like someone is protecting it.”

loans.use: To breed livestock, which will supply her retirement home with milk and meat

loans.name: Lulai

texts.en: Lulai T., 45, is married with 5 children.  She has 6 years of experience in the plantation business.  She sells to the general public 6 days per week.  She has no previous loans with SPBD.  Lulai expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala.  SPBD loans are Lulai’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, knifes, weedkiller chemical and fertilizer.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine started her fish business three years ago in a community market near where she lives. She is 42 years old, divorced and a mother with eight children. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty fish in the market and she is one among many. She buys fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Many people buy from her in the marketplace.

All Josephine's children are currently in school. She supports her children from her business proceeds. She depends on that for their food, school bills and sometimes their medical bills. She needs this loan to increase her stock of assorted fish so she can increase sales and income to support her children's education and business growth. She hopes to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To increase stock of smoked and dried fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds for his farm

loans.name: Lila

texts.en:
Mrs. Lila S., 30 years old, lives in Bholdhoka, Lalitpur. She lives in a joint family household with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, her husband, sister-in-law, brother-in-law and a daughter. The economic condition of her family is very weak. They are unable to even fulfill the basic needs of the family and can't provide a better education for her daughter.

Her husband, Suresh S., is a driver for a private office and her daughter is studying in grade 6.

Mrs. S. opened her vegetable shop two years ago to improve the living standards of her family. She also sells grocery goods in her shop. Now she is requesting Rs 20,000.00 to buy green vegetables and grocery goods for her shop.

Her family's economic condition is very poor, so Mrs Lila would like to grow her business continually and improve the standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Fulberto Antonio

texts.es: Fulberto Antonio M. Pérez tiene la edad de 41 años. Es un hombre casado y tiene 3 hijos menores de edad a su cargo. El se dedica a una pulpería. El tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000, ya que todos los financiamientos que ha realizado han servido de mucha ayuda para su negocio. El es un hombre muy trabajador y disfruta mucho de su trabajo. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, jugos, gaseosas y pan. A pesar de las dificultades que atravesó como fueron la falta de de capital propio. Su deseo es ampliar su negocio para que el día de mañana logre ser una distribuidora.
texts.en:
Fulberto Antonio is a 41-year-old married father of three dependent children. He owns and manages a small corner shop and has worked a lot with Fundación León 2000, since all of his repaid loans have helped his business a great deal. He is a very hard-working man and really enjoys his work. The loan that he requests is for working capital to buy sweets, juices, sodas, and bread. Despite the difficulties that he has encountered, such as a lack of capital, his wish is to expand his business so that in the future he can be a distributor.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Due to difficulties of life, Eduardo A. did not able pursue his studies in college. He helped his father in cultivating their farm lot by plating rice and vegetables after he graduated in high school. At the age of 21 he decided to marry Ludilyn of whom they are gifted with four children. At present, the two eldest is now in their secondary level of education while the two youngest are in their elementary grades. Being a responsible parent, they wanted to give their children a better future by giving them the best education they needed so long as they afford it. 

In this regard, the couple manages to help each other in earning income to support the needs of their children. Eduardo uses his tricycle transport to earn income while his wife engaged in selling food snacks and vegetables in their village. In this connection, Eduardo is asking to borrow loan from KIVA lenders the amount of PHP5, 000 for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle and maintenance of his wife vending business. He hopes that lenders will provide them support that will somehow lead to the progress of their business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en: This is Joselito P., a 42 year old businessman from Pooc II, Silang, Cavite. He is married to Adarna, 38, a factory worker. Two of their four children are in school: one in college, the other in pre-school. Joselito has operated a general store for eight years and, over the years, his business has grown steadily. Recently, he ventured into a scrap-buying business. Along with managing his general store, he buys all kinds of used metal scraps, used bottles, cartons, and old newspapers and sells them to bigger buyers who in turn sell them to bigger recycling plants and foundries. Joselito earns close to P15,000 a month from these business activities. Joselito is now on his 10th loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. He became a member in 2006. He has applied for a new loan of P15,000 to buy more items to sell at his store. In the future, Joselito wants to see his general store be bigger than what it is now, so he can help employ some of his neighbors. He is also saving a lot from his earnings to support his children’s education. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell at his store

loans.name: Urchig

texts.en: E. is 27 years old and lives with his mother in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his mother live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). With the help of his sister, E. operates a traditional boots and clothing business in his town. He and his sister began their business with working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD); since then, their working capital has grown to reach 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). His dream is to keep expanding his business and to, eventually, be able to afford to build his own house. E. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order so that he can purchase necessary fabrics and finishing materials for his clothes and shoes.

loans.use: purchasing fabrics and finishing materials for his clothes and shoes

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda Mayug, 51, earns a living through her sari-sari (retail) store. She also has a business in dress making in her neighborhood in Norala, South Cotabato.  She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to obtain a loan necessary for her business with a low interest rate. She has requested an amount of 12,000 PHP as additional capital for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: Groceries

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert is managing his farm lot in the village where they live. He is married to Marilyn and they have been blessed with four children: Jhon Mazel, 14, a high school student; Jezel Anne, 12; Jezza, 4 years old and Jhonnel, 2 years old.

Albert dreams of having high yields because this is the main source of their income. He hopes to borrow additional capital from KIVA lenders for the maintenance of his rice farming business. He wishes to get a loan amounting PHP 30,000 in order to purchase fertilizer, pesticides and other important things needed in his rice farming business. This amount of loan will be a big help in growing his business.

loans.use: Buy farming supplies

loans.name: Onyero

texts.en:
Onyero has a big store where she sells clothes and jewelry at retail prices to her customers. Onyero puts more hours in her business attending to her customers; she also has a good customer relationship with her customers. Onyero has two (2) children and her husband is a contractor.

This is the high season for her business and Onyero hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Rafael

texts.es:
El Sr. Rafael Insaurralde nació en Luque, vive con su madre en el barrio Ykaa de dicha ciudad, se dedica a realizar trabajos de plomería a domicilio, como por ejemplo todas las instalaciones de cañería de la cocina, baño, piletas y arreglo en general, también realiza trabajos de construcción de todo tipo.
El último crédito lo destinó a la compra de artículos sanitarios entre otros accesorios para terminar una obra. Opera con La Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 2008 mostrando una buena referencia de pago
El Sr. Rafael agradece la ayuda brindada por la Fundación ya que mediante la misma también pudo comprar herramientas para facilitar su trabajo.
texts.en:
Rafael Insaurralde was born in Luque. He lives with his mother in the Ykaa neighborhood of the same city. He works as a household plumber. For example, he does things like install pipes in the kitchen, bathroom, sinks; and he does general repairs. He also does all types of construction jobs. He used his last loan to by sanitary items and other accessories to finish a job. He has worked with the Paraguaya Foundation since 2008, and he has a good history of payment. Rafael is grateful for the help offered by the Foundation. With this help he was also able to buy tools to facilitate his work.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy plumbing items and accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Wcsl Makama/mabanta Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the WCSL Makama/Mabanta Primary Schools. These schools, WCSL Makama and WCSL Mabanta, were established by the Wesleyan Church of Sierra Leone. Since both schools from the villages of Mabanta and Makama operate on the same payroll, they have merged to seek a loan from Kiva through SMT.

Teachers from these institutions, like many other teachers within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Fifty-four-year-old Solomon S. K. (right) is the head master at the school. He was born in a village called Rogbin. He is married with 3 children, 2 of whom are in Junior Secondary Schools II (JSS II) while the eldest is in a Teachers' Training College pursuing a Higher Teachers’ Certificate. With his share of the loan, he will buy house-building materials to complete the house-building project he has started.

loans.use: Buy house-building materials

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 49-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Mahmoud has been selling fruits and vegetables since 2003. He sells oranges, apples, tangerines, lemons, iceberg lettuce, cucumbers, tomatoes, radishes and more, depending on the season. Mahmoud decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his family’s business. His family has been working as farmers. Therefore, he decided to open his fruits and vegetables shop in order to sell the things his family produces. This is the first time he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. With his loan, he intends to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell from other farmers so that he can increase and diversify his sales. His clients are people from his region, but mainly his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and his income.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Linus

texts.en:
Linus M. is a businessman who makes and sells bricks within the community where he lives. He started his business in 1998 after he finished his studies as a source of income. He is 38 years old and married with four (4) children living with him in Nambale Busia District. This is where he also does his business.

Linus wants to increase his brick production. That will enable him to achieve his goal of going large scale to be able to attain a profit that will ensure him economic sustainability and a better future for his family. To do this, he requires a loan of Ksh.10,000 that he will be repaying. He will save the profits generated from his business.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita B., 40, is from the village of Balatacan Bonifacio. She is married with five school-aged children. Jovita operates a store selling seafood including fish and shrimp. She has been in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jovita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from GDMPC and is now requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jovita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's school fees. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Mrs. Rima B. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhashipati which is located in Lalitpur district. It is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture.

Mrs. Rima B. lives with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Rajendra, is in the Nepal army and her son is studying in pre-primary school.

Mrs. B. started her goat-raising business three years ago to help her husband financially. Now she has five goats. She buys baby goats and sells them in the local market after four to five months. This business helps her to improve the economic conditions of her family.

Now, Mrs. B. is requesting an Rs 30,000 loan to buy ten more baby goats for her business. She will also use the loan to buy feed for her goats.

loans.use: To buy ten baby goats and goat feed

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce en détail des articles scolaires, comme la rentrée du troisième trimestre est proche, elle voudrait gonfler son stock d’articles scolaires pour mieux vendre c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de règles, bics, cahiers et autres. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman has an income-generating retail business involving school supplies.  Since the third trimester will be starting soon, she would like to expand her inventory of school supplies in order to have better sales.  This why she's requesting a loan from WAGES for buying rulers, pens, notebooks, and more.  She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying school supplies

loans.name: Loda

texts.en:
Poverty has inspired Loda to continue her studies in college until she graduates and earns her degree. She is 26 years of age now and married to a 40-year-old security guard at one of the offices in town. Loda’s marriage union has blessed her with two sweet and loving children, ages three and seven years old. Though Loda’s husband supports her and her children financially, the woman still wants to be productive in her own way to support her own education and the needs of her children. Her husband’s income is yet too small to support things her family needs to be able to experience life beyond poverty.

When Loda joined ASHI in 2003, she requested a loan to start a “sari-sari” (variety) store, selling inventories of foodstuffs, beverages and other basic commodities for people in their village to purchase conveniently. Frequently her business can't be sustained and she has had to periodically shut it down. The loans she has received have been a great help in restoring her business. Despite those circumstances, Loda makes sure that she maintains an excellent repayment record with ASHI and attends the weekly ASHI center meetings. Assisted by her husband in fulfilling her responsibilities to ASHI, Loda is now requesting a loan to improve her business and to fully achieve her dream of making it sustainable and profitable to be able to support her needs in her studies as well as the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a larger volume of grocery items and other basic commodities for her store inventories.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn N. is from the village of Research Minante in Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 59 years old. Evelyn is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a general store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 33000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Evelyn's fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Uuganchimeg

texts.en:
Uuganchimeg T., age 39, lives with her family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Currently, she lives in a house with her family and parents near Narantuul market which is close to her workplace.

Uuganchimeg has been selling Korean secondhand mattresses, bedding and linen since 2006. She is a modest, silent and responsible woman. She says, “When summer comes, tourist camps, resorts and hotels need bedding and linen so the sale of goods improves. I am thinking of saving revenue to repair my fence and build a house in Gachuurt Horoo, Bayanzurh district.”

Uuganchimeg is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more second hand goods at a wholesale price to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es: Alicia, de 54 años, vive en su casa, que es propia en compañía de sus 4 jóvenes hijos.Desde hace 7 años, empezó a fabricar billeteras artesanalmente, y sus hijos aun  pequeños le ayudaban en lo que podían. Hoy en día, uno de sus hijos diseña, el otro remacha y graba los dibujos a las billeteras y  ella es la  costurera oficial, que termina con el acabado de cada una de las billeteras, es así que trabajan en conjunto. Y cuando le realizan grandes pedidos, todos se esfuerzan para la entrega oportuna. Uno de sus hijos, es el encargado de guardar los diversos modelos que realizan, para mostrarlos a sus nuevos  compradores. Sus clientes asiduos, son los comerciantes informales, que semanalmente acuden a su casa para solicitar mas  pedidos, porque las billeteras que realiza son de buena calidad. Para mas adelante tiene planeado ampliar su negocio de fabricación de billeteras, además de construir su casa.Es el  doceavo préstamo que tiene con MFP, y se compromete en pagar sus cuotas puntualmente como hasta hoy, además esta muy satisfecha de trabajar con los integrantes de su grupo comunal, porque son muy responsables en el pago de sus cuotas.Alicia tiene planeado invertir el dinero solicitado en la compra de cueros y telas, para continuar trabajando en la confección de billeteras, pues desea  continuar progresando.
texts.en:
Alicia is 54 years old and lives in her own home with her four teenage children. Seven years ago, she began making handcrafted wallets and even her children helped out in whatever way they could. Today one of her children is responsible for making the designs, another secures the studs and etches the designs, and she handles the sewing and making the finishing touches to each of the wallets. Whenever they receive large orders, they must work together and strive to deliver on time. One of her children is in charge of maintaining samples of what they have created in order to show to new buyers. Her regular customers are informal merchants who come to her home on a weekly basis to place more orders because the wallets she produces are of good quality. In order to stay ahead, she plans to expand her wallet manufacturing business as well as build a house.

This is her twelfth loan with MFP. She commits to submitting her loan payments on time, like she does today. Alicia is very satisfied with the work of the members of her Communal Bank because they are responsible with their payments. She plans to invest the money she requested in the purchase of leather and fabrics so that she can continue manufacturing wallets and making progress.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase leather & fabric

loans.name: Jose Abraham

texts.es: José es de 63 años de edad es casado, tiene siete hijos cuatro varones y tres mujeres, cinco de ellos ya no dependen de él, junto con su esposa tienen establecido un negocio de venta de papas fritas y atol de arroz con leche es su localidad, sus ventas lo realizan todos los días por las tardes, durante el día presta sus servicio como albañil, juntos han sacado adelante su familia, solicita su segundo préstamo para incrementar su capital de trabajo, el crédito anterior lo cancelo puntualmente.
texts.en:
José, 63, is married and has seven children, four boys and three girls. Five of them no longer depend on him. With his wife he has set up a fried potato and atol de arroz (a drink made with rice and sugar) business in their location. They are open for business every evening. During the day he works as a bricklayer. Together they have succeeded in raising their family. He is asking for his 2nd loan to increase his working capital. He repaid his previous loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda Y. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Brenda is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Brenda raises pigs for fattening and sale. Brenda has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Brenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Brenda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Brenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby pigs

loans.name: Seiylkan's Group

texts.en:
Seiylkan S. is the leader of the group. She is 47 and married. She has raised three sons and two daughters; her two older sons and first daughter study at university and the other children are at school. Seiylkan is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as a taxi driver; when he is free he helps his wife with her work. Seiylkan started to breed cattle two years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. With that money she purchased two bulls and resold them at a higher price (23,000 soms) after fattening them. With money received from the loan, Seiylkan wants to purchase farm animals to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions and give her children a good education.

Gulbaira K., 48, is married. She has a son and a daughter; the son is a private entrepreneur and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Gulbaira and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding; they started this activity two years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms. They bought a cow and then after a month that cow was resold at the higher price (30,000 soms). With money received from the loan, Gulbaira wants to purchase cattle for breeding and some part of the loan she will spend to purchase hay.

Guljan I., 54, is married. Her husband works as a teacher at school and Guljan is engaged in livestock breeding. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions.

Roza M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 45 and married. She has two sons and a daughter; the first son studies at university, the second is at school and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Roza is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as an electrician. In 2009, Roza bought a bull for 8,000 soms and then, after fattening it, resold it for 11,000 soms. And since then she has been breeding cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of cattle. In the future, she wants to expand her business activity and provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase farm animals.

loans.name: Nimecio Walter

texts.es: Nimecio se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno cuya producción de leche lo vende a Pil Andina (Planta industrializadota  de leche), vive junto a su   esposa y sus hijos  los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar. Es su primer  crédito en Impro y el primero vía Kiva. El crédito lo solicita para la compra de ganado vacuno.
texts.en:
Nimecio raises dairy cows. He sells their production to Pil Andina (an industrialized milk plant). He lives with his wife and children. The children are school age. This is his first loan with Impro and his first through Kiva. He will use the requested loan to buy a dairy cow.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna M. is 55 years old and a widow. She is from the village of Calamagui within San Pablo municipality, a part of Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Edna raises pigs to fatten and sell. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3500 PHP whenever she sells one of her pigs.

In 2009 Edna joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. Edna is requesting a new loan, her fourth from ASKI, of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase more piglets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:
